review.title: Limits of Preprocessing
review.abstract: We present a first theoretical analysis of the power of polynomial-time preprocessing for important combinatorial problems from various areas in AI. We consider problems from Constraint Satisfaction, Global Constraints, Satisfiability, Nonmonotonic and Bayesian Reasoning. We show that, subject to a complexity theoretic assumption, none of the considered problems can be reduced by polynomial-time preprocessing to a problem kernel whose size is polynomial in a structural problem parameter of the input, such as induced width or backdoor size. Our results provide a firm theoretical boundary for the performance of polynomial-time preprocessing algorithms for the considered problems.

metadata.title: Limits of Preprocessing∗

sections.text: Combinatorial problems from different areas of AI. We look at problems from Constraint Satisfaction, Global Constraints, Satisfiability, Nonmonotonic and Bayesian Reasoning. We show that none of the problems considered, subject to a complexity theory assumption, can be reduced by polynomial pre-processing to a problem core whose size is polynomal in a structural problem parameter of the input, such as induced width or size of the back door. Our results provide a fixed theoretical limit on the performance of polynomial preprocessing algorithms for the problems considered. Keywords: fixed parameter tractability, constraint satisfaction, global constraints, satisfiability, Bayesian Networks, Normal Logic Programs, Computational Complexity.

sections.heading: 2 Formal Background

A parameterized problem P is fixable if there is an algorithm that solves each problem (x, k).

sections.heading: 3 Tools for Kernel Lower Bounds
sections.text: Subsequently, we will use recently developed tools to obtain lower kernel boundaries. In other words, our lower kernel boundaries are subject to the widely accepted complex theoretical assumption NP 6'co-NP / poly (or equivalent, PH 6 = х3p). In other words, the tools allow us to show that a parameterized problem does not allow a polynomic kernel unless the polynomial hierarchy collapses to its third level (see e.g. Papadimitriou, 1994). A composition algorithm for a parameterized problem P is an algorithm that accommodates a polynomial kernel (x1, k).

sections.heading: 4 Constraint Networks
sections.text: We have proven successful in modeling everyday cognitive tasks such as vision, speech comprehension, standard analysis, and abduction. The tuples of Ri indicate the permissible combinations of concurrent values for the variable Si.

sections.heading: 5 Satisfiability
sections.text: The prospective satisfaction of a problem (SAT) was the first problem that proved wrong (Cook, 1971). Despite its hardness, SAT solvers are increasingly leaving their mark as all-purpose tools in areas as diverse as software and hardware verification, automatic test pattern creation, planning, and even challenging algebra problems (Gomes et al., 2008). SAT solvers are able to exploit the hidden structure that exists in the real world. The concept of backdoors, introduced by Williams, Gomes, and Selman (2003), provides a means of explicitly defining the vague notion of a hidden structure. Backdoors are defined in terms of a "sub-solver," which is a polynomial time algorithm that correctly determines satisfaction for a Class C of CNF forms.

sections.heading: 6 Global Constraints
sections.text: A global constraint is a pattern that occurs frequently in the real world, for example, it is often required that all variables take different values (e.g. that each variable requires the same resource).The global constraint is defined for a set of variables, each variable x-variable x-variable requires a certain number of values (x).A global constraint is such a constraint that each x-variable x-variable defines a certain domain (x) of values. A global constraint defines which instances are legal and which are not. A global constraint is consistent if it has at least one legal consistency, and it is consistent (or hyper arc) if each x-variable is legal and which are not.

sections.heading: 9 Conclusion
sections.text: From these results, we conclude that, contrary to many optimization problems (see Section 1), typical AI problems do not allow polynomial cores. Our results suggest that alternative approaches should be considered. For example, it may still be possible that some of the problems considered allow polynomially large Turing cores, i.e. polynomial pre-processing to a Boolean combination of a polynomial number of polynomial cores. In the field of optimization, parameterized problems are known that do not allow polynomial Turing cores, but polynomial Turing cores (Fernau et al., 2009). This points to a theoretical and empirical investigation of Turing cores for the AI problems considered.

We consider problems from Constraint Satisfaction, Global Constraints, Satisfiability, Nonmonotonic and Bayesian Reasoning.
